text.front:
DOI: 10.1002/zaac.200700529
Tantalum(IV) Iodide, TaI 4 : A Molecular Solid Consisting of Dimers of Dimers,
Ta 4 I 16
Gerd Meyer a, *, Rafal Wiglusz b , Ingo Pantenburg a and Anja-Verena Mudring c, **
a Köln, Institut für Anorganische Chemie der Universität zu Köln
b Wroclaw/Poland, Faculty of Chemistry of the University of Wroclaw
c Bochum, Anorganische Chemie an der Ruhr-Universität Bochum
Received November 26th, 2007.
Abstract. Although incongruently melting at 398°C, single crystals
of TaI 4 were obtained as a by-product during a reaction which was
designed for Rb{Pr 6 C 2 }I 12 . The crystal structure of TaI 4 [triclinic,
P1 (no. 2); a ϭ 705.9(1), b ϭ 1062.3(2), c ϭ 1072.3(2) pm, α ϭ
79.55(2), β ϭ 89.78(2)°, γ ϭ 75.57(2)°, V ϭ 765.1(5)10 6 pm 3 ; Z ϭ
2, R1 ϭ 0.042 for I 0 > 2σ(I 0 )] contains tetrameric molecules which
consist of two face-sharing dimers of TaI 6 octahedra which share
text.body:
As (inorganic) solid state chemistry moves forward and contributes
increasingly to the world of materials science, properties of com-
pounds are being designed through growing complex compositions.
Basic binary compounds are thought to be understood Ϫ just text-
book knowledge! "Simple" iodides such as Sc 0.9 I 2 [1] and PrI 2 [2]
where composition, crystal and electronic structures and synthesis
play a strongly interdependent role teach us a different lesson. Fur-
thermore, it appears to be common thought that compounds of
fourth and fifth period elements are alike, subject to lanthanide
contraction [3]. A closer inspection exhibits that this is vaguely the
case for compounds in their highest oxidation states.
New halides of lower-valent early transition metals with unusual
structures ("clusters") have been the target of intensive research
already some fifty years ago [4]. Since then their structural chemis-
try has become monograph and even textbook knowledge [3] and
it is now believed that these systems are well "understood".
According to a (compositionϪtemperature) phase diagram deter-
mination, the binary tantalumϪiodine system contains three com-
pounds, TaI 5 , TaI 4 and TaI 2.33 [5]. Crystal structures were deter-
mined for TaI 5 [6] and for TaI 2.33 ϭ Ta 6 I 14 [7]. These two iodides
mark the most oxidized and the most reduced tantalum iodides.
Tantalum(IV) iodide, TaI 4 , was prepared several times by different

www.anjamudring.de
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 634, 825Ϫ828
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
825
a common edge. The Ta-Ta distance in the face-sharing dimers is
297.5(1) pm and may be associated with a single bond. Theoretical
calculations exhibit two degenerate HOMOs which are occupied by
four electrons; two four-center-two-electron bonds is, therefore, a
better description of the metal-metal bonding situation in Ta 4 I 16 .
Keywords: Tantalum; Tantalum iodide; Crystal structures
text.body:
routes [5, 8], see also ref. [9]. It was assumed that TaI 4 might con-
tain Ta 2 I 8 dimers similar to NbI 4 [10] which consists indeed of
chains of edge-sharing Nb 2 I 8 ϭ [NbI 4/2 I 2/1 ] 2 dimers [11].
The crystal structure of TaI 4 , however, has not been determined
previously because single crystals had never been obtained. This is
mainly subject to the decomposition of TaI 4 at 398°C [5], a tem-
perature which is rather uncomfortable for the growth of crystals
Figure 1 Crystal structure of TaI 4 . Projection onto (100) exhibi-
ting the ABAC closest packing of iodine atoms with one quarter
of the octahedral interstices occupied such that Ta 4 I 16 molecules
appear.
text.note: G. Meyer, R. Wiglusz, I. Pantenburg, A.-V. Mudring
text.body:
of such halides. From powder diffraction it became clear [5] that
there might be two modifications of TaI 4 mimicking the assumed
polymorphism of NbI 4 , but none of these are isostructural with the
crystal structure of α-NbI 4 [11].
Quite recently we had obtained single crystals of K 2 TaCl 6 and of
K 4 [Ta 6 C1 12 ]Cl 6 through oxidation of the wall of the tantalum reac-
tion container with vanadium(III) chloride [12], reactions that were
designed for ternary vanadium chlorides such as KVCl 3 . In a simi-
lar incident, during a reaction of RbI, PrI 3 , Pr and graphite in a
sealed tantalum container we have obtained a minor amount of
black well-developed single crystals of TaI 4 attached to the wall of
the tantalum container [13].
The crystal structures of all transition metal tetraiodides MI 4 which
were characterized by X-ray crystal structure analyses [11, 16] con-
sist of metal octahedra sharing edges in different ways to infinite
chains 1
ϱ [MI 4/2 I 2/1 ], see also [17]. The 4d 1 configuration of Nb 4ϩ in
NbI 4 gives rise to a metal-to-metal bond attested by alternating
Nb-Nb distances of 331 and 436 pm along the trans-edge-connec-
Figure 2 Electronic structure of TaI 4 . Top: Molecular orbital diagram for TaI 4 exhibiting the two degenerate four-center-two-electron
HOMOs and two still Ta-Ta bonding LUMOs seperated by a considerable energy gap. Below: Density of states (DOS) (total DOS in black,
Ta-d PDOS in blue, I-p DOS in red) and crystal orbital Hamiltonian populations (COHP) for Ta-Ta interactions.
text.note:
www.zaac.wiley-vch.de
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 825Ϫ828
text.body:
ted octahedral chains [11]. (Note that in ThI 4 ϭ [ThI 8/2 ] square
antiprisms are face-and edge-connected [18]).
Crystal Structure of TaI 4
According to our crystal structure determination [19], tanta-
lum(IV) iodide, TaI 4 , does indeed form dimers as was assumed
previously [3, 4, 8]. But they differ remarkably from the dimers in
NbI 4 . The TaI 6 octahedra do not share common edges. Rather, two
TaI 6 octahedra are connected via a common face which brings
the tantalum atoms much closer together, at a distance of only
297.5(1) pm. The face-sharing octahedra of the composition
[(TaI 3/2 I 3/1 ) 2 ] ϭ TaI 4.5 must be linked further to allow for the com-
position TaI 4 . Connection via common vertices would lead to a
chain as in β-ReCl 4 (below) [20]. Connection via one common edge
leads to a tetramer Ta 4 I 16 (Fig. 1). Connectivities are as follows:
I 3/1 Ta2(I 3/2 ) 2 Ta1I 1/1 (I 2/2 ) 2 I 1/1 Ta1(I 3/2 ) 2 Ta2I 3/1 ϭ Ta 4 I 8/1 (I f
6/2 I e
2/2 ) 2 ϭ
Ta 4 I 16 ϭ TaI 2/1 I 4/2 ϭ TaI 4 .

The crystal structure of TaI 4 may also be described in terms of an
ABAC closest packing of iodide spheres in which one fourth of the
octahedral interstices are occupied such that the just-mentioned
tetramers are built, which are isolated from each other.
In the Ta 4 I 16 molecules, the non-bonding Ta-Ta distance through
the common edge is 439.5(1) pm, much the same as the non-bond-
ing Nb-Nb distance in NbI 4 (436 pm) [11]. With 297.5(1) pm
through the common face of three iodide ions, the TaϪTa distance
is very close to the mean value of the twelve octahedral edges as
observed in Ta 6 I 14 , 292.3 pm [7b] and with the unbridged Ta-Ta
attractions in the pentameric (NH 4 ) 6 [{Ta 5 (NH) 4 }]Cl 17 [21],
293.2(1) pm. The only other tetrahalide which contains face-shar-
ing octahedra is ReCl 4 in the so-called β polymorph [20]. The
double octahedra with ReϪRe distances of 272.8(2) pm share, how-
ever, two common vertices resulting in a chain structure.
Electronic Structure of TaI 4
With one 5d electron per Ta 4ϩ , the TaϪTa distances of 297.5(1) pm
through the common faces in the tetrameric Ta 4 I 16 molecules in
TaI 4 may be associated with the formation of two TaϪTa σ bonds,
or, in other words, two two-center-two-electron bonds as suggested
in Fig. 1. Extended Hückel Molecular Orbital calculations [22] for
the molecular Ta 4 I 16 unit essentially support such a localized in-
terpretation although there are two degenerate HOMOs, which
correspond to two four-center-two-electron orbitals as depicted in
Fig. 2. The LUMOs are still bonding and it might, therefore, be
possible to further reduce TaI 4 . However, there is a considerable
energy gap between the HOMOs and LUMOs. This picture of the
electronic structure of TaI 4 is confirmed by DFT-LMTO-ASA cal-
culations for the bulk [23]. Here, a HOMO-LUMO separation of
about 0.4 eV is found as illustrated by the density of states (DOS,
Fig. 2). States below the Fermi level are dominated by iodine-p
contributions whereas the empty states above can be mainly attri-
buted to Ta-d states. The crystal orbital Hamiltonian populations
(COHP) for Ta-Ta interactions clearly show strongly bonding and
well localized Ta-Ta bonds, Figure 2.
Conclusions
We have serendipitously obtained single crystals of TaI 4 during a
reaction that was designed for Rb{Pr 6 C 2 }I 12 through a reaction
with the tantalum container. The crystals must have formed in an
unknown way during the cooling process because TaI 4 does not
exist in equilibrium above 398°C [5]. Powder X-ray diffraction data
previously recorded of a sample that was obtained by reduction of
TaI 5 with aluminium [5] are identical with those calculated from
the present single-crystal X-ray data, see Fig. 3. Accordingly, TaI 4
has an unprecedented molecular tetrameric structure which makes
it also reasonable that it is able to form complexes with pyridine
[5] whose structures are so far unexplored. TaI 4 , however, obtained
through decomposition of its pyridine complexes, has a different
crystal structure. Assumptions that TaI 4 has the same crystal struc-
ture as NbI 4 [24] based on powder diffraction data of a tantalum
"subiodide" which gave a green aqueous solution [8] had already
been disposed. Both TaI 4 modifications prepared either by alu-
minium reduction or by decomposition of the pyridine complex
"hydrolyzed rapidly with formation of a hydrous brown oxide" [5].
Thus, our present work represents the first determination of the
crystal structure (of one modification) of tantalum(IV) iodide.
text.note:
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 825Ϫ828

text.body:
Figure 3 Calculated powder diffraction data for TaI 4 with the first
11 lines indexed as observed previously from a powder obtained by
aluminium reduction of TaI 5 , see ref. [5] from which the right part
of the Figure was taken.
text.div:

freiheitsgraden und Unordnung").

176.
[11] L. F. Dahl, D. L. Wampler, Acta Crystallogr. 1962, 15, 903.
[12] K 2 TaCl 6 : L. Jongen, G. Meyer, Acta Crystallogr. 2004, E60,
i91; K 4 [Ta 6 C1 12 ]Cl 6 : L. Jongen, G. Meyer, Acta Crystallogr.
2004, E60, i100.
[13] Synthesis: Starting materials: PrI 3 was synthesized from the
elements as previously reported [14]. RbI and graphite were
G. Meyer, R. Wiglusz, I. Pantenburg, A.-V. Mudring
dried prior to use. All manipulations were then carried out in
an argon filled dry box (M. Braun, Garching). RbI, PrI 3 , Pr
and C were filled in 1:4:2:2 molar amounts in a previously
carefully cleaned tantalum tube which was sealed by helium-
arc welding. It was then jacketed by a silica tube which was
sealed under reduced argon pressure. The reaction was carried
out in a tubular furnace, at 1000 K for three weeks, then co-
oled to 850 K and kept there for another three weeks. Reaction
products were mainly Rb{Pr 6 C 2 }I 12 [15] and a small amount
of TaI 4 , not detectable in a powder X-ray diffraction pattern.
[14] a) J. D. Corbett, Inorg. Syntheses 1983, 22, 31; b) G. Meyer,
Synthesis of Lanthanide and Actinide Compounds (G. Meyer,
L. R. Morss, eds.), Kluwer Acad. Publ., Dordrecht, NL,
1991, 135.
[15] R. Wiglusz, I. Pantenburg, G. Meyer, Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem.
2007, 633, 1317.
[16] TiI 4 : S. I. Troyanov, Zh. Neorg. Khimii 1993, 38, 226; ZrI 4 : B.
Krebs, G. Henkel, M. Dartmann, Acta Crystallogr. 1979, B35,
274; HfI 4 : B. Krebs, D. Sinram, J. Less-Common Met. 1980,
76, 7; α-, β-PtI 4 : K. Brodersen, G. Thiele, B. Holle, Z. Anorg.
Allg. Chem. 1969, 369, 154; G. Thiele, W. Weigl, M. Degner,
Naturwissenschaften 1975, 62, 297; UI 4 : J. H. Levy, J. C.
Taylor, A. B. Waugh, Inorg. Chem. 1980, 19, 672.
[17] U. Müller, Acta Crystallogr. 1981, B37, 532.
[18] A. Zalkin, J. D. Forrester, D. H. Templeton, Inorg. Chem.
1964, 3, 639.
[19] Black single crystals of TaI 4 were selected under a microscope
in a dry box and sealed in thin-walled glass capillaries. After
their quality had been checked by Laue diffraction patterns,
the best single crystal was transferred to a single-crystal X-ray
diffractometer (Stoe Image Plate Diffraction System, IPDS I)
to collect a complete intensity data set at 293(2) K. Triclinic,
space group P1 (no. 2); a ϭ 705.9(1) pm, b ϭ 1062.3(2), c ϭ
1072.3(2) pm, α ϭ 79.55(2), β ϭ 89.78(2)°, γ ϭ 75.57(2)°, V ϭ
765.1(5)10 6 pm 3 ; Z ϭ 2, ρ calc ϭ 5.978 gиcm Ϫ3 ; 2.50 < θ/°<
25.00; Mo-K α radiation (λ ϭ 71.073 pm); F(000) ϭ 1140; μ ϭ
30.386 mm Ϫ1 ; 6927 reflections were measured, of which 2544
are unique. R1 ϭ 0.042 and wR2 ϭ 0.098 for [I 0 > 2σ(I 0 )]. The
data were processed with the program systems SHELX-97
[G. M. Sheldrick, SHELX-97 manual, University of Göttin-
gen, 1997]. Scattering factors were taken from International
Tables for Crystallography, Volume C [A. J. C. Wilson, Kluwer
Dordrecht, The Netherlands, 1995]. Numerical absorption
correction was performed after crystal shape optimisation
using the programs XRED and XSHAPE [Stoe, XRED 1.01
and XSHAPE 1.01, Darmstadt, 1996]. Further details on the
crystal structure investigation of TaI 4 may be obtained from
the Fachinformationszentrum Karlsruhe, 76344 Eggenstein-
Leopoldshafen, Germany (fax: (ϩ49)7247-808-666; e-mail:
crysdata@fizkarlsruhe.de), on quoting the depository numbers
CSD-391406.
[20] F. A. Cotton, B. G. DeBoer, Z. Mester, J. Am. Chem. Soc.
1973, 95, 1160.
[21] M. Simon, G. Meyer, J. Chem. Soc., Chem. Comm. 1993, 460;
Eur. J. Solid State Inorg. Chem. 1997, 34, 73.
[22] Semi-empirical extended Hückel calculations (EH) for the mo-
lecular unit (TaI 4 ) 4 were performed with the program package
text.note:
www.zaac.wiley-vch.de
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 825Ϫ828
text.listBibl:
CAESAR [J. Ren, W. Liang, M.-H. Whangbo, CAESAR,
PrimeColor Software Inc., Raleigh, NC, USA, 1998] with the
following parameters (double zeta-functions): H ij [eV], ζ 1 , co-
efficient 1, ζ 2 , coefficient 2: Ta: 6s Ϫ8.73, 2.0, 0.56742, 1.10,
0.56334; 6p Ϫ3.30, 1.64, 1.00, 0, 0; 5d Ϫ7.57, 3.30, 0.56438,
1.50, 0.61594; I: 5s Ϫ22.4, 3.20, 0.63024, 1.95, 0.44674; 5p
Ϫ11.17, 2.65, 0.59977, 1.45, 0.51361.
[23] Calculations of the electronic structure for the extended solid
were carried out using the tight-binding linear-muffin-tin or-
bital (LMTO) method in the local density (LDA) and atomic
sphere (ASA) approximation within the framework of the den-
sity functional theory (DFT) method [a) H. L. Shriver, The
LMTO Method, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, Germany, 1984; b) O.
Jepsen, M. Snob, O. K. Andersen, Linearized Band-Structure
Methods in Electronic Band-Structure and its Applications,
Springer Lecture Note, Springer Verlag, Berlin, Germany,
1987; c) O. K. Anderson, O. Jepsen, Phys. Rev. Lett. 1984, 53,
2571; R. W. Tank, O. Jepsen, A. Burckhardt, O. K. Andersen,
TB-LMTO-ASA Program, Vers. 4.7, Max-Planck-Institut für
Festkörperforschung, Stuttgart, Germany, 1998]. All major re-
lativistic effects except spin-orbit coupling were taken into ac-
count using the scalar relativistic approximation. The calcu-
lations include corrections for the neglect of the interstitial
regions and the partial waves of higher order. To reduce the
overlap of atomic spheres (AS), empty interstitial spheres were
added to the crystal potential and the basis set. Reciprocal
space integrations are carried out using the tetrahedron
method [a) O. K. Andersen, O. Jespen, Solid State Commun.
1971, 9, 1763; b) P. Blöchl, O. Jepsen, O. K. Andersen, Phys.
Rev. B. 1994, 34, 16223]. The basis set of short-ranged atom-
centered TB-LMTOs contained the 5d wave functions for Ta.
The 6s, 6p and 5f partial waves were included only in the tails
of the LMTOs according to the Löwdin downfolding pro-
cedure [a) W. R. L. Lambrecht, O. K. Andersen, Phys. Rev. B
1986, B34, 2439; b) O. Jensen, O. K. Andersen, Z. Phys. B.
1995, B97, 35; c) G. Krier, O. Jepsen, O. K. Andersen, Max-
Planck-Institut fur Festkörperforschung, Stuttgart, Germany,
unpublished]. For iodine 6s, 5p, 5d and 4f orbitals were con-
sidered as valence orbitals and 6s, 5d and 4f were downfolded.
To examine in detail the effect of different atoms on the elec-
tronic density of states, the partial (l and m quantum number
decomposed) electronic density of states has been calculated.
These were calculated by projecting the wave functions onto
spherical harmonics centered on each atom. For bond analysis
the crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (COHP) method
is used together with its integration, the ICOHP [R. Dron-
skowski, P. E. Blöchl, J. Phys. Chem. 1993, 97, 8617]. COHP
gives the energy contributions for all electronic states for selec-
ted bonds by partitioning the band structure energy in terms
of the respective orbital pair contributions. Note, however,
that the values are negative for bonding and positive for
antibonding interactions. Thus, the sign is inverted with
respect to the crystal orbital overlap population (COOP)
diagrams originally used in semi-empiric extended-Hückel
calculations [S. Wijeyesekera, R. Hoffmann, Organometallics
1984, 3, 949].
[24] L. F. Dahl, D. L. Wampler, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1959, 81, 3150.
